metaDescription: Fantastisk 3-bedroom town house in Pilar de La Horadada, Costa Blanca. €370,000. Perfect holiday home with Mediterranean lifestyle. 40% cheaper than island markets.
heroIntro: Imagine waking up to Spanish sunshine, stepping out onto your own piece of the Costa Blanca, and having nothing but Mediterranean relaxation ahead of you. This exceptional 3-bedroom, 3-bathroom town house in Pilar de La Horadada offers exactly that—a sophisticated holiday home escape priced at just €370,000. What makes this property extraordinary is its premium specification at a price that's 40% less than comparable properties on Spanish islands like Mallorca and Ibiza. You're not compromising on quality; you're simply buying smarter. With 114m² of thoughtfully designed living space set on a generous 200m² plot, this home strikes the perfect balance between intimate living and room to breathe. Whether you're seeking a sun-soaked retreat for summer escapes, a winter sanctuary from northern climates, or a strategic investment property, this residence delivers on every front. The Costa Blanca has long been the discerning traveler's secret—superior weather to the islands, more authentic Spanish culture, and a thriving international community that makes life wonderfully easy for foreign buyers.
areaSection: Pilar de La Horadada sits on the southern Costa Blanca, positioned perfectly between the cosmopolitan buzz of larger towns and the tranquility of a genuine Spanish coastal settlement. This charming municipality enjoys over 300 days of sunshine annually, with mild winters and warm summers that make outdoor living a year-round reality. The town has maintained its authentic Spanish character while quietly becoming a haven for international property buyers who value substance over hype. Its location is strategically advantageous—just minutes from pristine beaches with Blue Flag status, yet close enough to larger amenities and services. The surrounding landscape features the dramatic backdrop of inland hills, creating natural beauty without the overdevelopment that plagues other coastal areas. This is a place where Spanish tradition meets modern convenience, where you can enjoy a leisurely café con leche at a local bar or explore the region's rich history and culture.
lifestyleSection: Life in Pilar de La Horadada revolves around the unhurried rhythm of Mediterranean living. Your mornings might begin with a walk to one of the nearby Blue Flag beaches, where the water stays remarkably warm well into autumn. The town center buzzes with activity—weekly markets overflow with fresh local produce, family-run restaurants serve authentic paella and fresh seafood, and traditional tapas bars welcome both locals and the established international community. English is widely spoken here, making daily life seamless for foreign residents. The expatriate community is well-integrated, creating a supportive network without the expat bubble of overdeveloped areas. You'll find yourself shopping at modern supermarkets like Mercadona and Consum alongside locals visiting traditional markets. Healthcare is readily accessible through both private clinics and regional hospitals with English-speaking staff. For those seeking activity, championship golf courses punctuate the region, while cultural experiences—from fiestas to local museums—keep life interesting and connected to genuine Spanish culture.
investmentSection: Beyond its appeal as a personal holiday retreat, this property represents a sound investment opportunity in a market showing positive momentum. Costa Blanca property prices have risen 8% year-on-year, bucking the stagnation seen in other Spanish regions. At €370,000, this property sits above the Pilar de La Horadada average of €2,200/m² because of its premium specification and excellent condition—offering genuine value rather than inflated pricing. The rental market remains robust, with comparable holiday properties commanding approximately €800 per week, translating to strong annual returns if you choose to let the property during peak seasons. Many owners adopt a hybrid approach: personal use during preferred months, rental income during high-season weeks. The town's growing popularity among international buyers continues driving demand, while its relative affordability compared to island markets attracts serious investors seeking long-term appreciation without the premium island pricing.
conclusion: This €370,000 town house represents more than a property transaction—it's a gateway to the Mediterranean lifestyle you've imagined. Three bedrooms, three bathrooms, premium specification, and a generous private plot converge to create a holiday home that works equally well as a smart investment or a personal sanctuary. At 40% less than Spanish island markets, the value proposition is compelling. Pilar de La Horadada itself offers the perfect balance: authentic Spanish living, established international community, world-class beaches, and modern amenities without the overdevelopment plaguing more famous coastal towns. Whether you envision summer escapes with family and friends, winter refuge from harsh climates, or a strategic rental investment tapping into Costa Blanca's robust holiday market, this property delivers. The Costa Blanca isn't a new discovery—it's a proven, mature destination where thousands of British and European residents live happily, enjoying sunshine, affordability, and genuine Mediterranean culture. Despite its authentic Spanish character, the town offers everything modern residents expect—from world-class healthcare to international education options, quality shopping, and efficient transport links.

The regional hospital is positioned just 28 minutes away in nearby areas, while several private clinics throughout the region specifically cater to international residents and visitors. English-speaking doctors are commonly available, ensuring communication is never a barrier when seeking medical attention. For routine healthcare needs, health centers within Pilar de La Horadada itself provide quality primary care. The area has developed an excellent reputation for medical tourism, with many international residents praising the professionalism and affordability of healthcare compared to Northern European standards. Prescription medications are readily available and competitively priced.

shopping.text: Shopping in Pilar de La Horadada caters to both convenience-seekers and those who enjoy exploring local character. Major supermarket chains including Mercadona, Lidl, and Consum are strategically located throughout the town, offering familiar brands alongside Spanish products at competitive prices. Weekly markets burst with fresh produce, seafood, and local specialties—an authentic experience that connects you to the local community. For larger shopping expeditions, La Zenia Boulevard shopping center is just 8 km away, featuring international brands, restaurants, and entertainment. The result is a shopping experience that suits every preference—quick convenience shopping, cultural market exploration, or comprehensive retail variety all within easy reach.

transport.text: Getting around Pilar de La Horadada and the wider region is straightforward. While a car provides maximum flexibility—particularly for exploring the beautiful surrounding countryside and less accessible beaches—the town is navigable without one for daily needs. Public bus connections link Pilar de La Horadada to nearby towns and major centers, making car-free living feasible for those so inclined. Alicante-Elche Airport, serving numerous European cities including frequent UK connections, is just 48 km away (approximately 45 minutes by car). Alternatively, Murcia Airport provides another gateway for international flights. The road infrastructure is modern and well-maintained, making driving a pleasant experience rather than a stressful necessity.

faqs.question: Hvor mye koster denne eiendommen?
faqs.answer: €370,000. This 3-bedroom town house offers premium specification at this price point—notably 40% less expensive than comparable properties on Spanish islands. The price includes a generous 200m² private plot with multiple outdoor entertaining options.

faqs.question: Er Costa Blanca et godt sted å kjøpe eiendom?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. Costa Blanca ranks among Europe's most desirable property markets for foreign buyers, combining affordable Mediterranean real estate, year-round sunshine (300+ days annually), established international communities, and strong rental demand. The region is experiencing 8% year-on-year property appreciation, indicating healthy market fundamentals.

faqs.question: Kan utlendinger kjøpe eiendom i Spania?
faqs.answer: Yes, foreigners have identical property purchase rights to Spanish citizens in Spain. No special permits or restrictions apply to EU or non-EU nationals. You'll need a Spanish tax number (NIE) and must register the property at the land registry. Most foreign buyers engage a Spanish lawyer to navigate the purchase process—a worthwhile investment ensuring legal compliance.

faqs.question: Hva koster det å kjøpe eiendom i Spania?
faqs.answer: Beyond the €370,000 purchase price, expect acquisition costs of approximately 7-8% including transfer tax (6-8%), notary fees (0.5%), and legal fees (0.5-1%). Annual property costs typically include IBI property tax (0.4-0.6% of property value) and utility expenses. Hiring a Spanish lawyer (€1,500-3,000) ensures proper legal documentation and NIE registration.

faqs.question: Trenger jeg visum for å kjøpe eiendom i Spania?
faqs.answer: No, you don't need a visa specifically to purchase Spanish property. However, if you plan to reside in the property, visa requirements depend on your nationality. EU/UK citizens should explore residency options—the Spanish 'Non-Lucrative' visa has become increasingly popular for retirees and remote workers seeking legal residency while maintaining the property.

faqs.question: Hvor mye er eiendomsskatten i Spania?
faqs.answer: Spanish property tax (IBI) typically ranges from 0.4-0.6% of the property's cadastral value annually. In Pilar de La Horadada, you'd expect approximately €1,500-2,200 per year for this property. Additionally, wealth tax applies to high-value property portfolios. Your Spanish lawyer can provide precise tax estimates based on current regulations.

faqs.question: Kan jeg få boliglån i Spania som utlending?
faqs.answer: Yes, foreign buyers can obtain Spanish mortgages through Spanish banks and private lenders, typically securing 60-80% loan-to-value ratios. Interest rates remain competitive, often lower than UK equivalents. Banks require proof of income, credit history, and typically prefer applicants with Spanish tax registration. Many foreign buyers find working with a Spanish mortgage broker invaluable in securing favorable terms.

faqs.question: Hva er levekostnadene på Costa Blanca?
faqs.answer: Costa Blanca cost of living is substantially lower than Northern Europe—typically 20-40% cheaper depending on lifestyle choices. Groceries, dining, utilities, and entertainment remain affordable. This property's €370,000 purchase price reflects the region's accessibility compared to UK or Nordic property markets. Monthly living costs for a couple typically range €1,500-2,500 depending on activity level and dining preferences.

faqs.question: Er Costa Blanca bra for pensjonister?
faqs.answer: Excellent, yes. Costa Blanca has become a premier retirement destination offering affordable living, Mediterranean sunshine, quality healthcare with English-speaking doctors, and a mature expat community providing immediate social networks. The climate reduces heating costs, outdoor lifestyle supports healthy aging, and healthcare costs are significantly lower than Northern Europe. Many retirees find the combination of affordability and lifestyle quality superior to remaining in their home countries.

faqs.question: Hvordan er været på Costa Blanca?
faqs.answer: Exceptional year-round. Pilar de La Horadada enjoys over 300 days of sunshine annually with average temperatures of 17°C in winter and 28°C in summer. Mediterranean breezes keep temperatures moderate even in peak summer. Rainfall is minimal (200-300mm annually), concentrated in autumn and spring. This climate makes outdoor living feasible every month, reducing seasonal affective disorder common in northern climates.
